conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the motion based on the given acceleration-time graph.
The particle starts from rest, meaning the initial velocity is zero.
The acceleration is positive initially (from 0 to \( t_0 \)), then decreases to zero, becomes negative, and increases back to positive (from \( t_0 \) to \( 2t_0 \)).
From 0 to \( \frac{t_0}{2} \), acceleration increases linearly from 0 to \( a_0 \).
From \( \frac{t_0}{2} \) to \( t_0 \), acceleration decreases linearly from \( a_0 \) to 0.
From \( t_0 \) to \( \frac{3t_0}{2} \), acceleration becomes negative, starting from 0 to \( -a_0 \).
From \( \frac{3t_0}{2} \) to \( 2t_0 \), acceleration increases linearly from \( -a_0 \) to 0.

premise: The velocity-time graph is the integral of the acceleration-time graph.
conclusion: Velocity reaches a maximum when the acceleration first becomes zero (at \( t_0 \)).

premise: The particle continues to move in the positive direction until the velocity becomes zero again.
conclusion: The particle is farthest from the starting point when it reaches its maximum displacement.

premise: The particle is farthest from the starting point when it reaches its maximum displacement.
conclusion: This occurs when the velocity becomes zero again after reaching a maximum positive value.

premise: The particle reaches its maximum displacement (farthest from the starting point) when the velocity becomes zero after increasing and then decreasing.
conclusion: This happens at \( \frac{3t_0}{2} \), as shown in the second graph where the velocity returns to zero.

premise: From the v-t graph, it can be seen that the particle always moves in the positive direction.
conclusion: At \( t=2t_0 \), the particle is farthest from the starting point.
